bibl.title: Letter from Cornelia Knox Kean to Mary Standlee, May 4, 1951 [Enclosed in 06504022]

div1.p: Kean harshly criticizes Standlee's manuscript and states the reasons for her opinions. She includes a detailed list of corrections for the Standlee manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from Cornelia Knox Kean to Mary Standlee, May 4, 1951 [Enclosed in 06504022]
div1.p:
You have asked me to criticize your manuscript. It
is a difficult task for me, as I am not capable of doing
justice to the subject. I can only give you my point of view.

I was born in the Army many years ago. When my father
was ordered to Washington Dr. O'Reilly was the attending
Surgeon. There never was a nobler man, with a tender
sympathy for all mankind. In those days he made his
calls in a buggy, with a colored driver. I was a
child, and every morning I would stand on the corner of
21st and J streets to watch for him. He would lean out
the side of his buggy and give me his beautiful smile,
which made me happy. So you can see how I loved
him, and revered his memory.

In the old Army I think the Medical Officers were
judged, as were all men, by their character and ability. Of
course each branch had the pride of its own service and
esprit de corps.

The Spanish War was the end of an era. I never saw
Walter Reed, but I know how he was honored by Harvard
University, which was not the Army. General Kean loved
Cuba and his Cuban friends, so I know he would have been
unhappy to read page 36. He always gave Finlay the
Mrs. Standlee
2
gave Finlay the credit for the theory, and Reed the credit
for having demonstrated the theory. And General Kean always
worked for a friendly feeling between the Cubans and ourselves.
He and Dr. Finlay were friends. As I said to you the day
you were here, I hoped you would do, as I feel deeply, that
you would take Dr. Hench's work on Walter Reed and Yellow
Fever as Gospel, for that is the way General Kean felt.

You are a friend and admirer of General Kean's. I
like your term “judicial” for him. But on page 58 you
use “suave and adroit” as if the term astute politician
is meant. General Kean always worked for his country and
for the Medical Corps and the welfare of the Army. Certainly,
not for himself. He always gave all that he had to
those who sought him - of his learning, his generous cre-
ative gifts, and his sympathetic and constructive mind.
Always and Inspiration - even now - to those who knew
him and loved him. I like General Hume's ap-
preciation of General Kean, P. 237 of his History of the
Military Surgeon. Also I like the citation which
he received with the Gorgas medal.

I know there are those at Walter Reed who never
heard of Walter Reed except as the name of a Hospital, who
never heard of General Ireland, who never heard of
General Kean - Such is fame.

For your story why perpetuate the old jealousies and bitternesses?
3
Mrs. Standlee
To me Walter Reed Hospital is the most blessed place
on earth. There is glory enough for all who have ever
served it, with the tender care of human beings in distress.
The only place I know where money has no value. I would
like your story to be a tribute to Humanity, our
Country and our Medical Corps. This is the prayer
of an old Army woman born and bred, and I hope died,
at Walter Reed.

When you asked me to criticize your story, you told me
you would not be offended at anything I might say.
I have taken you at your word. If I can be of help
to you along the lines of my own convictions, I
would be glad to do so.

26 (26) In 1881 courtly, contentious Dr. Carlos Finlay
of Havana delivered a scientific paper before the Royal
Academy of Havana on the Mosquito Hypothetically considered
as the agent of Transmission of Yellow Fever. Few if
any of Dr. Finlay's contemporaries gave his theories
the consideration they deserved. And such is the re-
sistance to new ideas, if not self-propounded, that in
time the stubborn doctor was considered senile or
visionary or both.

47 Apart from the spectacular control of epidemics, which
followed the work of the Yellow Fever Board, these factors
assisted in immortalizing Walter Reed. Unlike the
combat services, the Medical Dept. then had few put-
licized heroes, and Dr. Reed's untimely death, at the peak of
his career, provided a Martyred hero for immediate adoption,
solving the epidemiology of Yellow Fever was indisputably a
major medical accomplishment, although it was by no means a single-
handed effort, a credit to one man alone. Yet as chairman

of the board, he received more recognition than his collaborators.
Thirdly and perhaps most important, his friends kept the altar
candles a light to his memory for half a century.

47 ... (52A) although Kean, McCaw, and Ireland came in time to
resent the favors and publicity which followed Gorgas
(52G) Gorgas likewise memorialized Walter Reed
48 ... (57) Defensively his friends became Sentinels to his memory.

48(G) ... In 1906 during the height of the controversy, Dr. Howard
(58) Kelly, with Major Kean's untiring assistance, produced a
Touching biography. With love and forsight zeal and
perseverance, they success fully canonized him for he
“being dead it (was) an obligation of his friends to see
that his scientific achievements (were) not forgotten.”
55(15) Interview with Gen. Kean

Dr. Borden ... been known as the physician to Presidents.
Others hinted that he was politically successful because he had
known Cleveland and that having once X-rayed Teddy Roosevelt's
knee he had obtained the listening ear of politicians.

57(25) Surgeon General Robert maitland O'Reilly was not a
spectacular successor to the professionally outstanding
General Sternberg, but he was a conservative and agreeable
man who endorsed sound policies. Any lack of aggressiveness was
P
3
57 was offset by his pleasant dignified manner and his
quiet plodding along a course founded by the Dodge Com-
missions recommendations and the enthusiasm of his young
satellites for administrative innovations. Field medical
officers were conscious of their lack of prestige with line
officers, with whom seniority, rank and responsibility were
nearly synonomous terms, and they were determined to over-
come the military handicap which doctors, as technicians,
met constantly in the highly organized caste system
fastered by the Army ((25) Kean April 17, 1950)

58 While General O'Reilly made an excellent impression on
Congressional Committees, he would not personally lobby far special
(26) interest programs, and so he detailed energetic young doctors
to key office positions and held them responsible for the of-
fice management. The resourceful and aggressive Dr. Borden
was offered the influential position of executive officer,
but as his primary interest lay in the professional field
he declined, saying he preferred being the “power behind
the throne”, although Borden had a personal career plan

(27) Toward which he worked, there were a good many would be
powers in those days, and he soon found that he had a
friendly rival in his alternate, Dr. Jefferson Randolph Kean,
who was appointed executive officer and became one of
General O'Reilly's principal advisers.

The two young doctors were opposite in type, temperament
and interests. The suave and adroit Kean.

P
58
was already well known as a practical sanitarian and
"trouble shooter" for the Department, but at this time
he was intensely interested in establishing a personnel
section in General O'Reilly's office, supervised by a doctor
rather than the autocratic civilian Chief Clerk. Further,
he disapproved of the allegedly patronage ridden system
of the National Guard and milita appointments and
favored formation of an Officer's Reserve Corps which
would guarantee a roster of professional men not only
familiar with military medical problems (28) but quickly
available in time of war.

A great deal of Kean's recent service had been in the
tropics, and he had come to believe that the medical officer
made a better sho of authority in effecting sanitary reforms
when addressed by a military title, for “doctor” was a self-
limiting term which restricted the holder to an ad-
visory (29) or service role. Kean agreed heartily with
Theodore Roosevelt's opinion that medical officers must
"supplement in (their) calling the work of surgeon
(30) with the work of the administrator." It was during
this period, therefore, that medical officers began
abandoning their professional title, adopting, almost
to the point of a fetish, the the military form of address.

113 Colonel Charles E. Mason succeeded Major Ashburn as
commander at Walter Reed on October 6, 1916. Author of a
handbook which the Military Surgeon called the medical
Soldier's “Bible”, he had long been interested in sanitary
tactics. Quiet, refined, scholarly and cultured.
Like Colonel Richards he was small of Stature. In
spite of his charming manners and the reputation of having
twice married beautiful women, by the time he became
the eighth Commander of Walter Reed a haunting, brooding
look of suffering had settled like a shadow on his face.
It was a time for action rather than for meditation, and
the tenure at Walter Reed may have been trying for the
some what melancholy officer whose record as man-
ager of the Ancon Hospital, Canal Zone, showed that he
had a flair for husbanding federal money.

I do not like - Gen. Kean was a friend of Col. Mason and of
his lonely wife. I think it poor taste to mention the
wives in a Military History, and Colonel Mason was a
sick man
C. Kean
